description: From Pasquino, a mutilated statue at Rome, set up against the wall of the palace of the Orsini; so called from a witty cobbler or tailor, near whose shop the statue was dug up. On this statue it was customary to paste satirical notes.

examples: The Grecian wits, who satire first began, / Were pleasant pasquins on the life of man.

verbs.description: pasquin (third-person singular simple present pasquins, present participle pasquining, simple past and past participle pasquined)
